Literature Review: The field of synthetic biology has emerged as a transformative approach to understanding and engineering biological systems, fundamentally shifting the paradigm from analysis to synthesis. This shift mirrors the historical progression in the chemical sciences, where synthesis has played a pivotal role in elucidating chemical principles and enabling the creation of novel compounds. In the context of biology, synthesis offers a unique lens through which to explore the complexities of life, enabling researchers to construct and manipulate biological systems in ways that were previously unimaginable. This literature review delves into the expanded central dogma of molecular biology, focusing on genome resynthesis, synthetic genetics, and the development of orthogonal biosystems, as highlighted by recent advancements in the field. Genome resynthesis represents a cornerstone of synthetic biology, offering a pathway to the de novo construction of genomes. This approach not only facilitates the study of genome structure and function but also enables the creation of organisms with tailored genetic makeups. For instance, the synthesis of the Mycoplasma genitalium genome marked a significant milestone, demonstrating the feasibility of constructing a bacterial genome from scratch (Gibson et al., 2008). Subsequent efforts have expanded the scope of genome synthesis, encompassing larger and more complex genomes, and paving the way for the engineering of novel biological functions. Synthetic genetics extends the traditional boundaries of genetic information storage and transfer by introducing unnatural base pairs (UBPs) and xenonucleic acids (XNAs). The development of UBPs, such as the d5SICS-dNaM pair, has enabled the expansion of the genetic alphabet, offering new possibilities for information encoding and the evolution of novel biological functions (Malyshev et al., 2014). Similarly, XNAs, which are synthetic analogs of DNA and RNA, have been engineered to replicate, transcribe, and even evolve, challenging the notion that nucleic acids are the sole carriers of genetic information (Pinheiro et al., 2012). These advancements not only deepen our understanding of the chemical basis of genetics but also open up new avenues for the development of synthetic organisms with enhanced or entirely new capabilities. Orthogonal biosystems represent another frontier in synthetic biology, characterized by the creation of biological components and pathways that operate independently of the host's natural systems. This orthogonality is crucial for the engineering of synthetic organisms, as it minimizes interference with native processes and allows for the precise control of synthetic functions. The development of orthogonal ribosomes, for example, has enabled the selective translation of synthetic mRNAs, facilitating the expression of proteins with unnatural amino acids (Rackham & Chin, 2005). Similarly, orthogonal DNA replication systems have been engineered to support the replication of synthetic genomes, further expanding the toolkit for synthetic biology (Marlière et al., 2011). Together, these advancements underscore the potential of orthogonal biosystems to revolutionize our ability to engineer life. In conclusion, the expanded central dogma of synthetic biology, encompassing genome resynthesis, synthetic genetics, and orthogonal biosystems, represents a paradigm shift in our approach to understanding and engineering biological systems. By leveraging the principles of synthesis, researchers are not only unraveling the complexities of life but also paving the way for the creation of novel biological entities with unprecedented capabilities. As the field continues to evolve, it holds the promise of addressing some of the most pressing challenges facing humanity, from healthcare to environmental sustainability.
